results.notes:
…or perhaps a look-alike unnamed species? There appears to be some evidence for splitting “rubrobrunneus”.
Near a border with a wooded area featuring mature shagbark hickory and young oaks.
Taste bitter.
Other fruit bodies found growing in the exact same area (previous years) had cap color showing more purple; eg. obs 207218, obs 139487, obs 138813.

Collected from a 3-4 square yard area where a sloped lawn borders a brushy area. Along the border there are several 20-25 foot tall oaks. These oaks were quite small when I first moved into the house here over 20 years ago. There’s also a very large shagbark hickory (Carya ovata) and mature white pines about 15-20 feet from the patch where the Tylopilus grows. Of the 20 summers that I have lived here 15 or more of those years featured one or more fruiting of large Tylopilus fruit bodies in this 3-4 square yard area. All tested for taste have been bitter. Cap color ranges from the brown as seen in 460899 to purple brown to dark purple. Stipe color is sometimes more pale than the one seen. In a few cases a thin but complete reticulatum covers the upper 10% of the stipe. In a few cases KOH applied to the cap surface caused a greenish-yellow reaction. Despite variability in cap color, I believe these have all represented the same taxon. I believe the Carya ovata is the primary associate (because other similar fruit bodies collected from other areas on my property have all been found close to Carya ovata trees). For years I have called all of these Tylopilis rubrobrunneus, which seemed to be the best morphological fit (despite the KOH reaction not matching what has been reported for T. rubrobrunneus). Interpreting ITS generated by the fruit body seen here suggests it does not represent T. rubrobrunneus.
Spore dimensions estimated as 9.5-12 × 3-3.5.
results.location_name: Property at 239 Golf Course Rd., Hunlock Twp., Pennsylvania, USA
Califon, New Jersey, USA

results.notes:
Solitary fruit body in mixed hardwoods.
For a number of years I had called the relatively small vividly yellow type “velatipes”. But I think “subvelatipes” may be a better fit for this type, although this particular example is perhaps large/robust for subvelatipes.
Update: As seen within the comments, the ITS matched several accessions labeled “Amanita multisquamosa”, and at least one other labeled “Amanita ‘sp. multisquamosa 04’”. Morphology does not line up with my concept of A. multisquamosa. But, my “velatipes” proposal was not supported by the DNA. This will be labeled “Amanita cf. multisquamosa” once submitted to GenBank.
Some additional meta-data on habitat: I revisited the collection site during February. There’s an advantage to doing this, as small trees (particularly conifers) otherwise obscured by understory are more easily seen during winter. The forest is almost all oak, hickory, and birch. Trees are mature but not particularly old. A few of the oaks feature trunks about 18 inches wide. The closest hemlock is over 100 yards from where this amanita was found. A bit closer, but outside of the interior of this hardwood forest, there is a lone mature white pine where the forest transitions to an open area near the park road. Emanating from this large white pine is a row of 10-12 white pine saplings, spaced about 15-20 feet apart with the one furthest from the large pine situated not far from where the amanita was found. These saplings are 2.5-4 feet tall and are likely obscured by the fairly thick understory during the summer. Other than these pine saplings, no other conifers were found within the interior of this hardwood area.

results.notes:
Boletes found at the base of Q. virginiana on UHouston campus. Brick-red caps, sterile margin, yellow pore surface. Stalks enlarged downwards with red tinge at base, all parts of mushroom instantly staining blue upon minimal contact. Similar to another bolete I saw on this campus that I identified as B. luridellus, with the main difference being the cap color. Saw these guys scattered around the area following a rain.
I was thinking that this might actually be Pulchroboletus rubricitrinus, but after comparing characteristics on wpamushroomclub the bulbous stem on these seems to not fit, and the photos on texasmushrooms show none with this style of stem. The lack of reticulation and no visible puntae (could just not see them) doesn’t indicate one or the other.

results.notes:
Two fruiting bodies growing 3-4 yards apart in mixed deciduous woods rich in oaks. I believe both are the same species/organism, so I am posting them together (large fruitbody = collection A; small fruitobody = collection B).
This is the same spot where the albino form of Amanita elongatior of obs 322318 was found in 2018. I don’t know if the present collection is the normal-looking elongatior; it’s possible for it to be another species. Also obs 370561 and obs 375028 were found in this spot in 2019, both having similar pigmentation to the present collection. I proposed A. elongatior for those two, but now I am not sure. At any rate, those were not collected. Sequenced collections of Amanita penetrans (obs 374001) and Amanita penetratrix (obs 372117) were collected in these woods and not too far away from this spot, so the area is very rich in sect. Vaginatae.
The cap of the mature collection A was 7-8 cm wide. The overall fruitbody height was 18 cm. Though some of the volval sack – its upper part – is visible at the bottom of the stipe, the stipe base/tip broke off (buried deep in the ground and a bit waterlogged). The in situ photos taken with a flash represent the cap color more accurately (yellow-tan) than those taken later in the open field in the shade (they look more brown there). Both fruitbodies had shaggy lower stipes, an unusual feature.

results.notes:
A NJMA foray collection. Found by Liz Broderick and myself in mixed deciduous woods and close to a caespitose quartet of huge red oaks. Liz posted this collection in obs 458842.
This species is morphologically assignable to sect. Validae. It was originally identified in the field by me as Amanita “sp-54”, but now I am leaning toward Amanita “sp-10” because the former species has a gray-brown cap devoid of volval remnants and a striate cap margin (an unusual and rarely observed feature in sect. Validae). I am not familiar at all with either species, and both have similar spore dimensions and shapes. Hopefully, DNA will tell us what it is (nrDNA accessions of “sp-54” are in GenBank, but no genetic data for “sp-10” has yet been disclosed by RET).
Specimen preserved & fresh tissue sampled in SDS buffer.

Basic Microscopy:
Spores mounted in Melzer’s and measured only in side/profile/dorsi-ventral view.
[40/1/1]: L x W = 7.0~8.4 × 4.65~5.6 (-5.9) μm; L’ x W’ = 7.6 × 5.1 μm; Q = (1.33-)1.37~1.63 (-1.70); Q’ = 1.49
Hyaline, amyloid, smooth, non-gutulate to occasionally having a faint granular content, thin-walled, adaxially (dorsally) flattened or occasionally slightly depressed, with a suprahilar disk absent or rarely barely showing, abaxially pot-bellied (some spores looking almost like half circles), ellipsoid (36 spores) to occasionally lower-end elongate (4 spores).
==========
RET reports the following measurements for “sp-10”:
[120/6/5] (6.6-) 7.3 – 9.5 (-12.5) × (4.7-) 5.3 – 6.3 (-7.8) µm, (L = 7.8 – 9.2 µm; L’ = 8.4 µm; W = 5.5 – 6.0 µm; W’ = 5.8 µm; Q = (1.18-) 1.30 – 1.62 (-1.73); Q = 1.37 – 1.55; Q’ = 1.46)
http://amanitaceae.org/?Amanita%20sp-10

RET reports the following measurements for “sp-54”:
[20/1/1] (6.0-) 7.0 – 7.8 (-8.0) × (4.0-) 4.5 – 5.5 (-5.6) μm, (L = 7.4 μm; L’ = 7.4 μm; W = 5.0 μm; W’ = 5.0 μm; Q = (1.36-) 1.38 – 1.60 (-1.64); Q = 1.49; Q’ = 1.49).
http://amanitaceae.org/?Amanita%20sp-54
My measurements are in excellent agreement with those reported by RET for “sp-54”. However, the average spore size for “sp-10” exceeds that of “sp-54” in either direction by no more that 1 micron and the Qav values are essentially the same. Overall, the appearance of this collection is perhaps more consistent with “sp-10” (brown cap, no-striate cap margin, round and shallowly rooting bulb).
Conclusion (posted 16-Apr-22): The ID by DNA is “sp-54” by DNA (full-length consensus sequence of two reads).

results.notes: Close to Neoboletus luridiformis auct. amer. This is fruiting all over CT wherever there is open parkland with mature oak. The cap is plush velvet, chocolate in color with deep burgundy tones. The pores start deep carmine red and age the pale orange. There is a yellow ring of sterile tissue on the outer edge of the pore surface, Cut flesh is bright yellow for a half second then bright blue. After a minute blue dulls and flesh appears dull cream. The stipe has a yellow ground color overlain with fine red punctae or squamules. A yellow ring appears at the apex where red punctae failed to develop

results.notes:
Habitat: very rotten wood adjacent to the log in the photo. Low, dank, primarily deciduous woods but eastern hemlock can’t be ruled out as substrate

Gills: close to crowded, free
Stipe: 50 mm long and 2 mm thick at apex expanding downward to 3 mm at the slightly expanded base. White, furry except where handled, possibly bruising yellow when touched
Flesh: white, fragile and quick to decompose
Odor and taste: not distinctive

MushroomExpert and Champignons du Quebec differ on the microscopic form of the pileipellis, with the ME key listing it as a cutis. C du Q calls it a trichoderm. Could we split the difference with “enterocutis”?

results.notes:
Two unique specimens found at the Whitemarsh Preserve in Savannah, GA this past winter, growing in mixed hardwood/pine forest. The mushrooms were found already removed from the substrate they had been growing in, but were next to a decaying oak log with several smaller mushrooms that looked similar; I am guessing they had been growing on that log as well. They reached almost a foot in height and had very soft, fuzzy caps and stems. I did not get a spore print, unfortunately.

I have posted these photos to several identification groups (iNaturalist, a local mushrooming group) but have never gotten a definitive ID — answers are usually split between Pleurotis sp. and Panus sp.. I have never seen mushrooms like this before or since and am very interested to know what they are.

results.notes: Found on dead wood, probably hard wood but reddish, possibly coniferous, but quite decayed. Found various different small sizes and maturity but all reddish purple, many with whitish bloom on center of cap and some with darker margins. I thought I saw shades of green or blue on some of the stems but could have been anticipating that. Not really cespitose, a couple small groupings but often solitary. Spore prints were dull, definitely not orange; I think they were white/creamish but may have been light brown. I’m frankly confused. Photos don’t match previous citings of luteofolius and spore print suggested it was not. But still not sure what else it could be. Please help with identification

results.notes: Collected and split with John Plischke. Growing scattered in leaf litter along the edge of a trail. Tsuga canadensis, Fagus grandifolia, Betula sp., Prunus serotina, Viburnum sp., Crataegus sp. and Hamamelis virginiana nearby. Caps up to 3.5 cm wide. Stems up to 1.4 cm wide. Spore print white. Spores hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (6.8) 7.4 – 8.4 (8.8) × (5.7) 6.2 – 7.1 (7.8) µm, Q = 1.1 – 1.3 (1.4); N = 30, Me = 7.9 × 6.6 µm; Qe = 1.2.

results.notes: 7 fruiting bodies collected with John Plischke. 1 fruiting body given to him as a split. Growing scattered in a mowed grass lawn. Young cap margin inrolled. Caps up to 2.4 cm wide. Stems up to 3.3 cm long. Cap and stem context white. Odor not distinctive. Taste strongly “mushroomy”, like Agaricus bisporus. Spore print white. Fusiform cheilocystidia scattered, some with encrusted apices. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores amyloid and warted. Spore measurements: (6.5) 6.8 – 8.6 (9) × (4.5) 4.6 – 5.2 (5.4) µm, Q = 1.4 – 1.7 (1.8); N = 30, Me = 7.5 × 4.9 µm; Qe = 1.5.

results.notes:
Young annual fruiting body on Western hemlock. Will monitor to maturity(granting no one removes it).
Growth updates on 7/30/21.
Growth updates on 8/6/21. Nearing full maturity. White leading edge very thin, yellow band thinning, slight spore drop visible(adhering electrostatically to cap). Sliced a small portion from this fruit and dried for home herbarium collection. Many of my fruiting locations have been unfortunately harvested by other folks. Pores measure 2-3 per mm. A quick note on pore size. Ganoderma oregonense pores are very dense, small when very young(pre-spore drop) and before planing will often measure 4-6 per mm before planing/maturing. It is likely that most all early collections of what was considered to be G. tsugae in the past we’re simply immature fruits of G. oregonense(as this collection had 5-6 pores per mm two weeks ago when measured). Always wait for spore drop and universal/nearly completely Maroon lacquered cap surface before harvesting and taking spore measurements underneath with this species. Genetic analysis and DNA sequencing have all turned up G. oregonense for Westcoast collections of Western Hemlock infecting specimens of varnished Ganoderma. None have been positively confirmed as G. tsugae. The early harvesting and miscalculation by early keys has contributed to this confusion. I will continue to monitor this fruiting until full maturity(fingers crossed that no one harvests it before).
Update 8/13/21: Fully mature and completely covered in spores(electrostatically dispersed and adhering to cap). Area where I sliced a sample last week(on 8/6/21) now completely healed over.
Cap: uniform maroon color, margin thin at maturity.
Pore measure: still 2-3 pores per mm.
Harvested near base and left 3inches to begin rapid regrowth. I expect another fully mature sporocarp by mid October(as with prior seasons).
Sliced and dehydrated for use in medicinal tea over winter months and saved a small slice to add to my labeled herbarium bag for this observation.
results.location_name: Watershed Park, Olympia, Thurston Co., Washington, USA

results.notes: Collected and split with John Plischke. Growing abundantly on the undersides of Picea abies logs in a log pile. Odor not distinctive. Hymenium surface dry. Surface olive to black with 1M KOH (tested on dried basidiocarp). Odor not distinctive. Monomitic with simple-septate generative hyphae. Hymenium layered. Cystidia smooth and subulate. Cystidia measurements: (35.8) 49.4 – 58.5 (65.2) × (3.5) 4.2 – 5.3 (5.8) µm, Q = (9.1) 9.6 – 12.8 (14.4); N = 30, Me = 53.3 × 4.8 µm; Qe = 11.2. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores smooth, thin-walled and inamyloid. Spore measurements: (3.2) 3.9 – 4.9 (5.2) × (1.8) 2.1 – 2.6 (2.7) µm, Q = (1.3) 1.7 – 2.2 (2.3); N = 30, Me = 4.4 × 2.3 µm; Qe = 1.9.

results.notes:
7/20/21 MM: Macro: medium brown, slightly glossy convex areoles. Where crowded, areoles with apothecia, 1-2 per areole, in other areas scattered and without apothecia. Apothecia dark reddish brown, sunken, generally taking up most of the areole. Micro: No interascal plectenchyma, no hyphal bundles interrupting algal layer. Thallus cortex measured 46 um, with clear syncortex on top ~5 um thick. Conidia very small <3 um long. Paraphyses 1.5-2 um wide, tips expanded to ~4 um wide. Hymenium difficult to discern, but measured ~75 um.

Chemistry: Thallus C+R, discernible (barely) under dissecting microscope, easily in section.

results.notes: Collected with John Plischke. 1 fruiting body given to him as a split. Growing in 2 clusters in moss and grass in the cemetery lawn between 2 Acer saccharum trees. Cornus sp. nearby, with a Quercus sect. Lobatae further away. Caps smooth. Gills notched to adnate with eroded margins and bruising punkish initially. Cap, stem and gill surfaces discoloring black with age/drying. Context gray in both cap and stem. Odor not distinctive. Taste strongly farinose and slightly bitter. Liquid from cut stems staining paper pinkish red. Spore print white. Pileipellis a transition between a cutis and a trichoderm. Clamps present in the pileipellis and lamellar trama. Pleurocystidia mostly absent except for tranisitional cystidia near the gill edge. Cheilocystidia smooth, hyaline, thin-walled and with a very variable morphology: lageniform, fusiform, flexuose or clavate, some with branched apices. Cheilocystidia measurements: (20.9) 22.9 – 51.3 (69.1) × (3.8) 5.3 – 8.3 (12.5) µm, Q = (2.5) 3 – 7.7 (8.6); N = 30, Me = 33.6 × 6.9 µm; Qe = 5. Basidia clavate and 1-sterigmate to 4-sterigmate. Some basidia with refractive content in Melzer’s and a phloxine/congo red/ammonia mixture. Basidia measurements: (25.9) 26.7 – 35.7 (36.8) × (5.3) 5.34 – 7.2 (7.4) µm, Q = (3.8) 4.2 – 6.2 (6.3); N = 20, Me = 30.9 × 6.1 µm; Qe = 5.1. Spores amyloid, hyaline, thin-walled and smooth. Spore measurements: (5.6) 6.3 – 7.4 (8) × (3.1) 3.5 – 3.9 (4.7) µm, Q = (1.6) 1.7 – 2; N = 30, Me = 6.9 × 3.7 µm; Qe = 1.8.

results.notes:
A NJMA foray collection.
A robust small- to medium-sized russula found in mixed deciduous woods by unknown foray participant. Heavy for their size and dense-fleshed. Cuticle doesn’t peel (no cuticle?), very crowded gills, no odor, flesh tastes neither bitter nor acrid, but rather just unpleasant and chalky. Couldn’t key it out in Kibby & Fatto based on the observable features. One fruitbody preserved, other two taken by John Burghardt.

results.notes: Originally passed over the mushrooms assuming they were nothing (caps looked too rusty) came back and ran a pic through a online AI powered mushroom ID tool to maybe point me in the right direction. Spores are purple brown. Also these mushrooms here were described to have a “spicy” and “cinnamon sort of spicy” smell. Habitat was spot in, flood plain with hardwood debris. We are quite late in the session. If not the said species could someone please explain where I went wrong? Still my first season. Also I think it’s worth noting the overall size of the shrooms where bigger then psilocybe caerulipes, stipe had a ring, with remnants of one on specimens without.

results.notes:
Pileus: light, greenish-beigish edges that become a darker green toward the center. Roughly 3.5 in. diameter. Evenly round, plano convex with a defined divot in the center. Dull and smooth. Slightly sticky when wet.

Stipe: Creamy white. Fibrillose. Roughly 0.5 in. diameter. Maintains a uniform thickness from ground level to cap. Slightly spongy interior and woody exterior. Snaps cleanly.

Volva: N/A

Annulus: N/A

Gills: crowded, creamy white. Bluntly attached

Spore print: pending

Observations: Found by a pond in a mixed hardwood forest after heavy rains. Growing directly from the ground as an individual fruiting body with others scattered nearby. Very mild, slightly sweet flavor.
